I guess you already fixed the problem, but I reply this for my relief.  f(x) = ln(1+x), f'(x) = 1/(1+x), which is (1+x)^(-1)   so by the rule we usually do, f''(x) = (-1) * (1+x)^(-1-1) → (I think this point is you missed) = -(1+x)^(-2), which is -1/(1+x)^2  as a result, f(0) = ln(1+0) = ln(1) = 0  f'(0) = 1/(1+0) = 1/1 = 1 f''(0) = -1/(1+0)^2 = -1/1^2 = -1/1 = -1

+Ritik Bompilwar starting off with a quadratic. so f-prime will leave x^2 as 2x and then f-double prime will leave this as a constant. When you plug in zero for f-double prime, there is no x but only a constant, or 2c. So you solve for c by dividing the f-double prime of x(0) by 2.
